entry.title: Charging of service items to additional service providers in SAP S/4 HANA Transportation Management
entry.content:
This blog post will help readers, customers, and SAP TM users familiarize themselves with the SAP Transportation Management‚Äôs functionality to carry out execution of additional services and associated payments in S/4 HANA 2023.

In this blog post I will be shedding light on carrying out additional service payment by eliminating the need to create additional documents thus reducing process complexity. The process may vary on the business needs and situational in nature.

You can read more about SAP S/4HANA Transportation Management -Settlement in the Application Help for SAP S/4HANA

Settlement | SAP Help Portal

Note: I have carried out the demonstration based on my personal tests, observations, insights in S/4HANA 2023 release with relevant screen shot from an internal system for ease of understanding. There‚Äôs no relevance or relation to any external source.

Use Case

Use case is for both the customers in Transportation & Logistics Industry (T&L) as well as shippers from Retail, CPG, manufactures etc. operating via Road and have to pay Additional fees for services incurred during or before executing the journey e.g. cleaning, fumigation or insurance etc over and above the contracted charges to an external party. The nature of the charge may be incidental in nature and not applicable for moves.

Assumption: 

The customer is a Manufacturing company and has implemented SAP S/4HANA 2023 and uses embedded SAP Transportation Management.

They have yearly contracts with the multiple road carriers to move certain capacities on a given corridor/ route. Alternatively, they have transportation network across different geographics which involves multiple entry and exists at the border crossing posts involving fees associated towards documentation/processing fees etc. As mentioned earlier this is applicable only if the truck crosses the border here by making it extremely important to track such services and associated charges.   The charges may vary depending on the border crossing location as each border crossing is managed by external parties. Contract in the SAP TM world should be referred as FRA (Freight Agreement).

Challenge:

  • SAP S/4HANA 2022 and lower releases supported such a scenario by creating an additional document termed as a service order which was linked to the associated freight order.
  • A service order as mentioned involves a cumbersome task to process it manually or an enhancement to automate the service order creation and associated settlement.

Solution:

SAP TM now has an out of the box solution to enable charge calculation and settlement for a service incurred in a freight order depending on the location and time of the service. This eliminates the need to create an additional document i.e. the service order and also the stage alternation (Intermediate stop) in the freight order isn‚Äôt required to identify the border crossing location.

 (*Depending on the scenarios, Service orders can be leveraged and its significance should be evaluated on a case-by-case basis)

Note: There are multiple ways in which the additional agreement party can be determined be it via std partner determination profile config or via an available BADI, and purely based on the business rule.

Scenario:
A manufacturer is moving goods from its facility in Canada to a customer in US and can be routed via a border crossing across three different points i.e.

  1. Fort Erie
  2. Niagara Falls ‚Äì Rainbow Bridge
  3. Niagara Falls ‚Äì Whirlpool Rapids Bridge

Border crossing across three different points - Designed by Aditya Shinde only for representation purpose.Determining the shortest or most applicable route is not in the scope of this blog post. Every border crossing location is operated by an external party and charges vary depending on the location/Service provider. The manufacturer is entitled to pay an associated fee depending on multiple factors but here we will consider service provider and service location as the prime driver to identify payable amount.

Let‚Äôs move directly at an instance in time where a road FRO is created with 1 active stages with executing carrier along with Border crossing agent as the Additional agreement party. The truck will cross the border via Fort Erie

We have valid Service types, Freight agreement i.e. 1 for executing carrier and 1 for Border crossing agent.

We start with an assumption that Order management, planning, Charge management and settlement configs are in place as the focus is not on setting up the system but on functionality walk-through.

Pictorial representation of the demonstrated scenario:

Fort Erie border crossing point - Designed by Aditya Shinde only for representation purpose.Basic process flow (Representation purpose only) 

Step 1:  Road FRO is created with executing carrier determined.

 Step 2 : Border crossing agent BP added as Additional agreement party.

As mentioned earlier there are multiple ways to determine a BP for Additional agreement party. For demonstration purpose I have added the BP manually and executing/invoicing carriers may be determined subcontracting process.


Step 3: Once the carriers are determined, you can observe that a special service by the name ‚ÄòBC- Border crossing‚Äô is assigned to the freight order.

 Important aspect to note here is that we have added 4 important values that play a pivotal role in triggering and performing charge calculation:

  1. Service type
  2. Check box (Item specific service provider)
  3. Service Location
  4. Duration.

 In the absence on the Check box (Item specific service provider), system will assume the service is performed by the executing carrier and will have to be maintained as part of executing carrier‚Äôs freight agreement and will get activated based on the associated service. There by payable to the executing carrier.

Once the above information is captured, you may save the freight order or execute charge calculation manually from the freight order.

Below is the result of the charge calculation.

 

Note: Charge structure and associated charges are for representation purpose and are fictitious in nature.


Step 4:  Freight order stages ‚Äì Important observation here to make a note is that the stage of the freight order is unaltered here by reducing efforts to trace the border crossing location.

Step 5: Determining charge based on the border crossing location at stage level is possible by leveraging std calculation base.

 Here you can observe that the charge is determined via a rate table.

Rate table created having a calculation base as SRV_LOCATION which identifies the service location.

Alternatively, you can use SRV_DURATION ‚Äì Service Duration as well to perform charge calculation.

In today‚Äôs demonstration, I have considered only service location based calculation.

The screenshot below demonstrates that system was able to initiate FSD creation for all of the applicable payable parties. 
 

The screenshot above demonstrates that no errors were observed during freight settlement document creation process and we can proceed with posting for accruals.
 
Note:
With the introduction of this functionality we can eliminate the introduction of service order which is an additional object and try to keep the process simple and reduce enhancement wherever applicable. Some exceptions may apply based on business scenarios and should be evaluated accordingly.

The demonstration in this blog post doesn‚Äôt focus on the configs to setup the system nor does it highlight all of the business rules associated with different industry sectors for the carrier payments.

Hope this article helps all of us understand and simplify the payment process associated with additional services incurred during transportation across various industries in the SAP S/4HANA Transportation Management world. There may be multiple different ways in which a contract may be negotiated between two parties, in this demonstration, I chose to keep it generic and simple.

Thank you for taking time and effort to read this.

Feedback/comments in any form will be highly appreciated.

entry.title: Supply Chain Logistics Maturity Model: Reaching the Horizon ‚Äì Orchestration at Level 4 (post 5 of 5)
entry.content:
The ultimate destination in the Supply Chain Logistics Maturity Model is Level 4: "Autonomous and Optimized". This is where logistics operations are not just efficient, visible, and resilient, but truly orchestrated. Companies here leverage the full power of AI, automation, and predictive/prescriptive analytics, fueled by real-time internal and external data, including market conditions, weather, and traffic. Decisions on loads, routes, and carrier selection are continuously optimized with minimal manual oversight. Collaboration extends across the entire network, engaging partners in joint planning and execution. Visibility is comprehensive, tracking shipments across all modes, directly alongside business processes for order and fulfillment management, down to the SKU level, providing reliable ETAs informed by global risk monitoring.

Level 4 represents the highest state of logistics maturity, characterized by:

  • Fully integrated, autonomous orchestration technology.
  • Predictive risk and shipment execution insights.
  • Ecosystem collaboration and logistics visibility in the context of business operations.

While achieving Level 4 is aspirational, it serves as a critical objective and a benchmark for industry leaders. It represents the state where logistics drives clear competitive advantage by enabling exceptional resilience and customer satisfaction. For companies aspiring to this level, the model helps in measuring performance against the highest possible standards ‚Äì looking at metrics like the percentage of automated transactions, time to resolve exceptions, on-time delivery rates, and the speed of onboarding new partners. It emphasizes continuous optimization, leveraging network-level data and collaboration for ongoing value creation. The improvement focus at this stage is on achieving true multi-tier supply chain automated Orchestration.

Reaching this stage requires integrated technology and robust network connectivity. SAP supply chain logistics solutions, including SAP Transportation Management, SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration, and SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace, are designed to provide the capabilities needed to improve at every level, from basic digital processes to advanced optimization and network collaboration.  

Regardless of where you are on the journey ‚Äì just starting out at Level 1, gaining traction at Level 2, building momentum at Level 3, or striving for full orchestration at Level 4 ‚Äì the Supply Chain Logistics Maturity Model provides a tool for self-assessment along with a direction towards improvement. By assessing your current state relative to the capabilities common at each level of maturity, you can chart your course for improvement, transforming your logistics operations to meet the today‚Äôs challenges and seize the opportunities of tomorrow.

We invite you to review the Supply Chain Logistics Maturity Model and chart your path to logistics excellence.

(prior post in this series)

Learn more about SAP‚Äôs supply chain logistics suite.

entry.title: 3-Level Advanced Intercompany Stock Transfer
entry.content:
Overview

Currently, Advanced ICo Stock Transfer functionality, delivered as part of SAP S/4HANA 2023 FSP2 Private Cloud/On Prem Edition, only supports a 2-Level business process. This business process comprises of exactly 2 legal units of a group, where in one legal unit, known as Receiving Company, purchases goods from second legal unit, known as Delivering Company.

The following diagram depicts the above-mentioned as-is stock transfer business process.

However, certain companies/businesses require a 3-Level Intercompany Stock Transfer business process, which involves an intermediary legal unit, which sits in between the Receiving Company and the Delivering Company.

 

3-Level Structure and Business Flow

  • 3-Level Intercompany Stock Transfer process comprises of 3 legal units of a group, where in one legal unit, known as Receiving Company, purchases goods from another legal unit, known as Delivering Company, via an intermediary legal unit, known as Intermediate Company.
  • From a business flow perspective, the Receiving Company purchases these goods from the Intermediate Company, which in turn purchases these goods from the Delivering Company.
  • The Delivering Company delivers the goods directly to Receiving Company, i.e., the Intermediate Company does not receive the goods in a physical Plant.

This structure is used when legal, tax, or commercial reasons require the flow of ownership to pass through an intermediate legal entity, even though the goods are never routed through its warehouse or plant.

While creating the STO we provide the selling and delivering company whereas the intermediate company is identified using Financial Chains.

 

Financial Chain Format

Delivering Company/Plant ‚Üí Intermediate Company/Transit Plant ‚Üí Receiving Company/Plant

 

How Financial Chains Are Determined

Once the Financial Chains are defined in the system, a separate determination setup is created to decide which Financial Chain applies for a given transfer.

This setup uses the following key criteria:

  • Process Type
  • Material Number
  • Delivering Plant
  • Receiving Plant
  • Earliest Requested Delivery Date

 

When a Stock Transport Order is created in the Selling Company, system checks the above combination and financial chain id is assigned for each item in the STO.

Below diagram depicts the 3 level Stock transfer process:

Activity diagram for the 3 level process is as below:

 

Value Chain Flow 

The process comprises the following key steps:

  1. Stock Transport Order in Receiving Company (Initiating Step)
  2. Intercompany Purchase Order from Receiving Company to Intermediate Company (Synchronous Step)
  3. Intercompany Sales Order in Intermediate Company (Synchronous Step)
  4. Intercompany Purchase Order from Intermediate Company to Delivering Company (Synchronous Step)
  5. Intercompany Sales Order in Delivering Company (Synchronous Step)
  6. Outbound Delivery in Delivering Company (External/Manual Step)
  7. Goods Issue for Outbound Delivery to SIT in Delivering Company‚Äôs Delivering Plant (External/Manual Step)
  8. Goods Issue from Issuing SIT in Delivering Company (Plant) to Intermediate Company (Synchronous Step)
  9. Goods Receipt in Intermediate Company‚Äôs Transit Plant (Synchronous Step)
  10. Inbound Delivery in Receiving Company (Synchronous Step)
  11. Goods Issue from Intermediate Company‚Äôs Transit Plant SIT to Receiving Company (Synchronous Step)
  12. Goods Receipt in Receiving Company‚Äôs Receiving Plant SIT (Synchronous Step)
  13. Goods Transfer from SIT to Physical Stock in Receiving Company‚Äôs Receiving Plant (Synchronous Step)
  14. Intercompany Customer Invoice in Delivering Company to Intermediate Company (External/Manual Step)
  15. Intercompany Supplier Invoice in Intermediate Company from Delivering Company (Synchronous Step)
  16. Intercompany Customer Invoice in Intermediate Company to Receiving Company (Synchronous Step)
  17. Intercompany Supplier Invoice in Receiving Company from Intermediate Company (Synchronous Step)

 

Benefits of 3-Level ICO Setup

  • Enables flexible supply chain structures
  • Complies with tax/legal structures across countries
  • Aligns with group-level financial control strategies
  • Optimizes logistics with direct delivery, while preserving legal flow

 

Summary

The 3-Level Advanced Intercompany Stock Transfer process extends beyond the standard 2-level scenario by introducing an intermediate legal entity for financial flows, while maintaining a direct delivery model for physical goods.

This 3-level stock transfer process is in line with the standard multi-level stock transfer process that is there in the future roadmap.

Technical details will follow in upcoming blogs.

entry.title: Vendor Risk Analysis Using AI Probability feature ‚Äî A Data-Driven Way to Pick Better Suppliers
entry.content:
üîóTry the Live App: vendor-risk-analysis-7pevu6jdyyunwukxau8japp.streamlit.app

üí≠Real Talk: We've All Asked This Before‚Ä¶

"I have a critical delivery next week. Which vendor is most likely to get it to me on time?"

It sounds like a simple question‚Äîbut when you actually dig into vendor KPIs, it‚Äôs hard to tell. One supplier has a high on-time percentage but a few big misses. Another always delivers‚Äîbut with an unpredictable delay.

So I decided to build a little app to help with exactly this.

üõ†Ô∏è What I Built (and Why)

This prototype started as an experiment. I wanted to go beyond just on-time % and bring probability into the picture‚Äîbecause supply chain planning is messy, and we need smarter ways to assess vendor risk.

So I made a tool that:

  • Takes your delivery data (CSV format) (With SAP AI- This can be automated)

  • Lets you filter by material, location, or recent months

  • Plots PDF and PMF charts (don‚Äôt worry‚ÄîI‚Äôll explain)

  • Calculates a quick, no-fuss vendor risk score

And the best part: it‚Äôs visual, interactive, and super easy to use.

Here‚Äôs a quick peek at what you‚Äôll see:

üìòQuick Refresher: PDF vs. PMF

üîçConcept üìà What It Tells You ü§î Example Question

PDF (Probability Density Function)How delays are spread out‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the chance of a delay between 2‚Äì5 days?‚Äù
PMF (Probability Mass Function)How often a specific delay occurs‚ÄúHow frequent is exactly 0 days of delay?‚Äù

By visualizing both, you get a complete picture: not just averages, but volatility and certainty too.

üßÆ How I Score Vendor Risk

To keep things practical, I used a simple formula:

Risk Score = Average Delay + 2 √ó (% Late Deliveries)

It‚Äôs not a PhD-level model‚Äîbut it does the job. Vendors with consistently late shipments or unpredictable spikes stand out quickly.

üß™ Built With

  • Streamlit for the UI (lightweight and fast)

  • Python, Pandas, Matplotlib for the brainwork

  • CSV input so anyone can try it with real or dummy data

üéØTry It Yourself

Explore the POC at

üîóvendor-risk-analysis-7pevu6jdyyunwukxau8japp.streamlit.app

‚úÖFilter by material or region
‚úÖZoom into any vendor
‚úÖSpot risky suppliers in seconds

ü§ñWhat If This Could Talk Back?

This got me thinking‚Ä¶ What if I could ask the app questions instead of reading graphs?

‚ÄúWhich vendors in Europe have a high chance of 3+ day delays for Material-X in Q2?‚Äù

Or

‚ÄúShow me suppliers with stable delivery patterns for critical parts.‚Äù

This is where Generative AI APIs come in. With a few tweaks, this app could:

  • Use OpenAI or SAP GenAI Hub to parse natural-language queries

  • With SAP AI , you can port this Python code and  take it from POC to  Enterprise APP.
  • Surface risk insights without you lifting a finger
  • Even generate automatic weekly risk reports in plain English

Related Work: MRP Exception Analyzer

If you liked this one, check out my earlier blog on an MRP Exception Analyzer I built using GenAI.
It turns SAP error codes into plain-language explanations:
üëâSAP AI Certified & My First GenAI Prototype: MRP Exception Analyzer

entry.title: SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration Q2 2025 - What's New?
entry.content:
Q2 2025 has been an exciting quarter for SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration, bringing a rich set of innovations that simplify asset management, enhance data usability, and strengthen collaboration between asset operators, OEMs and service providers. This quarter focuses on advancing master data management, improving work order processes, and expanding integration and API capabilities to support seamless and standardized operations. Whether you're managing material data, processing equipment entry, or working with shared notifications and work orders, these updates are designed to help you work smarter, faster, and more collaboratively across your asset ecosystem.

 

Material Outbound Integration

Scope:

  • Support ERP outbound replication of materials to models between SAP ERP and SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration

Key Benefits:

  • As an asset operator, you can replicate components assigned to work orders and work order operations from SAP ERP to SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration. Consequently, you can share the work order operations with the corresponding components to an external service providers so that the service providers has a complete overview on the work to be performed and the required spare parts.

Description:

  • This feature allows you to perform outbound sync of material data from ERP to models in SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration. The associated material classes, characteristics, characteristic values, and documents are replicated as model templates, attributes, data sheet, and associated documents for the model.

    For more information, see Materials.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Assignment of Components to Work Orders and Work Order Operations

Scope:

  • Assignment of Components for Work Orders & Work Order Operations

Key Benefits:

  • Enable customers to replicate ERP materials to SAB Business Network Asset Collaboration models
  • Component suppliers and product manufacturers can leverage this feature to share technical information about their spare parts and products with SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration, starting from the corresponding existing materials in SAP ERP
  • Asset Operators can leverage this feature to share spare parts (i.e. components) associated to specific work orders and work order operations to external contractors, starting from the corresponding work orders and work order operations in SAP ERP (i.e. SAP Plant Maintenance)

Description:

  • For work orders and work order operations, you can now see a new tab called Components. Here, you can view the list of attached components and their related information. You can also share this list of components with your external contractors.

For more information, see Viewing a Work Order and Viewing the Operations to be performed for a Work Order.

 

Asset Administration Shell File Upload for Models (i.e. Types)

Scope:

  • You can now upload single AASX files through the user interface, facilitating the creation of model entries in SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration based on Asset Administration Shells (AAS). This enhancement streamlines the import process by associating the AAS-standardized submodel ‚ÄúHandover Documentation‚Äù efficiently.

    For more information, see Import Data.

Key Benefits:

  • Automate model creation with documents to significantly reduce manual data entry and the risk of errors
  • Simplify entry into advanced data ecosystems with AAS-compliant interfaces that eliminate the need for complex custom integration with broader data ecosystems, such as Factory-X

Description:

  • Upload methods: upload .aasx files either through the user interface
  • Asynchronous processing: handle the upload and creation process for the model and documents asynchronously and use the process ID to allow the data steward to monitor the progress
  • Result visibility: empower the data steward to check the status (success or failure) through the process ID and view the resulting model and associated documents in the Model application once the file is processed
  • Conflict management: specify whether to ignore or update existing equipment and document associations during upload if they already exist in SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Attribute-based Search for Documents

Scope:

  • Provide the ability to search and filter documents based on document attribute values

Key Benefits:

  • Find and filter the right documents based on attribute values
  • Consume document standards and corresponding attributes in daily business processes

Description:

  • You can now search for documents using the search field.

  • As part of the document search, you can filter the documents . A new filter option based on the document template is also available .

  • Attribute based search is also enabled.

 

Asset Administration Shell File Upload for Equipment

Scope:

  • The new feature allows you to upload a single AASX files through the user interface, facilitating the creation of equipment entries in SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration based on Asset Administration Shells (AAS). This enhancement streamlines the import process by associating AAS - standardized Submodels Digital Nameplate and Handover Documentation data efficiently, making it more user-friendly.

    For more information, see Import Data.

Key Benefits:

  • Automate equipment creation with digital nameplate and documents to significantly reduce manual data entry and the risk of errors
  • Integrate with SAP Plant Maintenance for smooth synchronization of digital twin data with existing maintenance processes, which helps ensure that the latest equipment data, along with its associated documentation, is readily available for maintenance teams
  • Simplify entry into advanced data ecosystems with AAS-compliant interfaces that eliminate the need for complex custom integration with broader data ecosystems, such as Factory-X

Description:

  • Upload methods: upload .aasx files either through the user interface
  • Asynchronous processing: handle the upload and creation process for the equipment, digital nameplate, and documents asynchronously and use the process ID to allow the data steward to monitor the progress
  • Result visibility: empower the data steward to check the status (success or failure) through the process ID and view the resulting equipment, digital nameplate, and associated documents in the Equipment application once the file is processed
  • Conflict management: specify whether to ignore or update existing equipment and document associations during upload if they already exist in SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration

 

Other Innovations

  • Header PATCH API for equipment
    • This feature allows you to update values for header fields of the specified equipment using the PATCH API. For more information, see Equipment API.
  • Specify values for components in model structure
    • This feature allows you to assign and maintain quantity values for each component in the model structure. The model record creation now supports the assignment of precise quantity or quantity range with decimal values based on the base Unit of Measure (UoM) of the assigned component, if the base UoM is different than Each and Piece. For more information, see Creating a Model.
  • Templates for notifications
    • You can now add templates to notifications to maintain and share attributes related to the notification. For more information, see Creating a Notification.
    • The APIs are enhanced for the same. For more information, see Notifications API.
  • New APIs for work orders
    • GET API available to retrieve a list of templates associated with a work order.
    • PUT API available to modify attribute value in a work order.
    • For more information, see Work Orders - API.
  • Notification enhancements
    • As a service provider, you can view the shared status of the notification in the list page. For more information, see Sharing a Notification.
    • You can edit the priority of notifications as long as they are not shared or synchronized with the ERP system. For more information, see Creating a Notification.

 

Upcoming Innovations

Following exciting innovations are planned for the upcoming major release of SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration:

  • Header PATCH APIs for functional locations
  • Representing and sharing product families and configurations
  • Integration of ERP Materials to BNAC Models (brownfield/mapping)
  • Enablement of advanced search for technical objects on Azure
  • Public GET & POST APIs for Work Order-Operation - Collaboration Statuses
  • Collaborative statuses for notifications
  • Asset Administration Shell REST APIs
  • Etc.

 

Submit innovation requests

We encourage you to visit the SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration Customer Influence Portal to submit your innovation requests and review and vote innovation requests submitted by other customers.

entry.title: Complete your Advanced Shipping & Receiving (ASR) process with a PGI event
entry.content:
A common requirement in TM-EWM projects is the need to update the execution status or report an event on freight orders after the PGI. When configuring the Advanced Shipping & Receiving process, it is possible to specify the event that should be reported after the goods movement in the outbound processes.

This makes it possible to make your process more agile and cohesive, and to provide feedback to your freight order with all the necessary information, aiming to have a single point of reference for the process progress.

For this purpose, SAP provides the TM Save Strategy called PGI_REP_EV shown in the print below, which must be configured in the freight orders relevant to the ASR process:

After the entire process is executed in the ASR, our freight order will have these events, where the next step is the execution of the PGI and then the departure from door, which are executed in the Load or Unload Freight Orders app. Without the above configuration, only during the "departure from door" step is an event reported, which in this case is "Departure From Door".

This way we go to the "Load or unload Freight Orders" App and perform the PGI:

And this way, the "Checkout" event is reported. Additionally, according to the ASR process itself, the "Departure From Door" event is automatically reported. This occurs through the /scmtms/cl_tor_set_dep_wh_door-set_wh_door_departed class/method, which performs a series of additional checks to report this additional event along with the "Checkout" event. This way, we complete the entire process with just the PGI.

Therefore, it will not be necessary to run this departure process on the monitor:

An important point is that it's possible to configure the event that will be reported for this strategy. As mentioned above, the reported event was "Checkout". This event was determined through a process controller parameter linked to the method and the standard strategy. However, the class is prepared to be configured with a custom strategy (ZPGI_REP_E) and a custom parameter (ZEVENT_CODE), so you can determine which event will be reported via configuration:

To do this:

  • Create your own strategy according to the name described in the code and include the same method as the standard strategy
  • Create the parameter also with the custom name described
  • And then assign the event code to the parameter and strategy in this last menu of the process controller configuration:

entry.title: A Strategic Advantage of Transforming Your Supply Chain with SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP)
entry.content:
In today's dynamic market, a resilient and agile supply chain is not just an operational necessity, it is a competitive differentiator. For business and technology leaders, the time to modernize legacy supply chain systems is now. SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) offers a robust, future-proof solution that delivers tangible benefits.

Why Moving from SAP APO, ERP, or Legacy-Based Supply Chain Planning to SAP IBP is Your Next Strategic Investment:

1. Unified & Intelligent Planning:

  • One Source of Truth: SAP IBP provides a common data model across strategic, tactical, and operational planning, eliminating silos and ensuring consistency from end-to-end.
  • AI-Powered Network Insights: Embedded AI with Conversational, Agentic and network capabilities enable advanced planning beyond your organizational boundaries, both upstream and downstream, for smarter, more proactive decisions.

2. Agility & User Empowerment:

  • Self-Service & Flexibility: Business users can independently make changes, generate reports, and conduct analytics without constant IT intervention. Planners can even execute data and network changes in the live system.
  • Seamless Integration: With an open architecture and native real-time integration to SAP ERP (ECC/S/4HANA/Cloud ERP) and other application platforms, SAP IBP ensures data fluidity and process interoperability across your enterprise.
  • Scenario Planning: Supporting real-time simulations and unlimited, flexible what-if scenarios

3. Rapid Value & Future Readiness:

  • Quick Time to Value: Out-of-the-box capabilities and pre-configured industry processes (25+) mean faster implementation and quicker realization of benefits.
  • Scalable & Low TCO: Designed for scalability without customization, SAP IBP reduces maintenance burdens and delivers high ROI and a low Total Cost of Ownership.
  • Continuous Innovation: SAP's strong commitment to investment means quarterly feature releases, near-zero downtime upgrades, and a roadmap shaped by customer feedback, ensuring your supply chain stays ahead of the curve.

The Bottom Line:

SAP IBP is not just another planning tool; it is a comprehensive platform that empowers your organization with real-time visibility, intelligent decision-making, and unparalleled agility. Investing in SAP IBP means investing in a supply chain that can adapt, innovate, and drive significant business value.

An accessible  economic validation study for references:

  • Infographic

Sundar Ganesan, SCM Customer Evolution, SAP America Inc.

entry.title: The Next Industrial Revolution: AI Agents At The Heart Of Transformation
entry.content:
The manufacturing sector has always been at the forefront of innovation. From the steam engine to the assembly line, each leap has redefined what‚Äôs possible on the shop floor. Today, we stand at the threshold of another seismic shift‚Äîone powered not just by machines, but by intelligence itself.

The World Economic Forum‚Äôs latest whitepaper, ‚ÄúFrontier Technologies in Industrial Operations: The Rise of Artificial Intelligence Agents,‚Äù paints a compelling picture of this new era.

Why Now? The Case for Frontier Technologies

Industrial operations have long relied on innovations such as robotics and the industrial internet of things (IIoT) to drive productivity and efficiency. But the challenges facing manufacturers today are as complex as they are urgent. Labor shortages, rising costs, volatile supply chains, and the relentless push for sustainability are all converging. Manufacturers must not only optimize cost and efficiency but also adapt to rapid change, ensure resilience, and meet sustainability goals.

Traditional technologies, while powerful, are no longer enough to meet these demands. The answer lies in embracing what the WEF call ‚Äúfrontier technologies." Those that push the boundaries of what‚Äôs possible and unlock new forms of collaborative intelligence between humans and machines.

But why the focus on AI agents, and why now? The answer is simple: AI agents are not just another tool in the digital toolbox. They represent a new paradigm‚Äîone where software and robots can autonomously perceive, decide, and act, freeing up human workers to focus on creativity, strategy, and innovation.

The Rise of AI Agents: Virtual and Embodied

Success requires a leap beyond incremental improvement‚Äîtoward near-autonomous, AI-centric operations that empower people and machines to collaborate seamlessly.

The whitepaper highlights two main types of AI agents driving this transformation:

1. Virtual AI Agents: The Digital Workforce

Virtual AI agents operate within software environments. Think of them as digital colleagues‚Äîalways on, always learning, and capable of making decisions in real time. These agents can act as assistants, advisers, or even fully autonomous controllers, handling everything from production scheduling to predictive maintenance.

For example, a virtual AI agent might monitor a production line, identify bottlenecks, and automatically adjust workflows to optimize throughput. In supply chain management, these agents can analyze vast amounts of data, anticipate disruptions, and recommend alternative sourcing strategies‚Äîoften before a human would even notice a problem.

2. Embodied AI Agents: The New Robotics

Embodied AI agents take things a step further. These are robots equipped with advanced AI, capable of perceiving and interacting with the physical world. Unlike traditional robots, which are limited to repetitive, pre-programmed tasks, embodied AI agents can adapt to changing environments, handle complex assemblies, and even collaborate safely alongside human workers.

Picture a robot that can not only pick and place components but also recognize when a part is defective, adjust its grip, or reroute itself to avoid an obstacle‚Äîno manual intervention required. This is the promise of embodied AI: robotics that are as flexible and intuitive as the people working beside them.

Redefining the Human Role

One of the most exciting‚Äîand perhaps misunderstood‚Äîaspects of this transformation is the role of people.

Karim Lakhani, a professor at Harvard Business School, when asked, ‚ÄúWill AI replace humans?‚Äù, famously replied, ‚ÄúOf course AI won‚Äôt replace humans. But humans with AI will replace humans without AI.‚Äù

Far from replacing humans, AI agents are designed to augment human capabilities. As operations become more autonomous, the role of the worker evolves from hands-on operator to orchestrator and innovator.

Strategic Imperatives: Building the Foundations

Of course, realizing the full potential of AI agents requires more than just deploying new technology. Manufacturers must lay strong organizational and technological foundations:

  • Governance and Change Management: Leadership must champion the transformation, fostering a culture of innovation and trust.
  • Skills and Training: Upskilling and reskilling are essential, with a focus on digital literacy, data analysis, and collaboration.
  • Data and Infrastructure: High-quality, accessible data is the lifeblood of AI. Robust connectivity, cybersecurity, and scalable computing power are non-negotiable.
  • Ecosystem Collaboration: No company can do it alone. Partnerships across the value chain‚Äîsuppliers, technology providers, academia‚Äîare key to accelerating innovation.

Looking Ahead: From Experimentation to Transformation

The journey to AI-driven, near-autonomous operations is just beginning. Early adopters are already seeing tangible benefits, from reduced energy consumption to higher product quality and more resilient supply chains. But the real prize lies ahead: a future where manufacturers can respond to change with agility, drive sustainable growth, and empower their people like never before.

As the white paper concludes, manufacturers who embrace frontier technologies today will be the leaders of tomorrow. The Intelligent Age is here‚Äîare you ready to seize it?

Want to learn more about how AI-powered supply chains meet today‚Äôs needs while preparing for tomorrow? Check out this IDC Analyst Brief: ‚ÄúAI-Powered Business Suite for Supply Chain."

entry.title: SAP Supply Chain Management Certification: Increase Your Expertise and Credibility
entry.content:
Running sustainable, resilient supply chains amid disruptions has become a driving force in many organizations. While supply chains have historically prioritized efficiency and cost reduction, digital technologies are delivering incredible gains to achieve even greater outcomes, while connecting processes and enabling faster insights.

In these times of rapid innovation, it‚Äôs becoming increasingly more critical to stay informed of the latest positioning guidance for SAP supply chain solutions. SAP has addressed this need by offering a non-technical certification option: Positioning SAP Business Suite via SAP Supply Chain Management Solutions. The non-technical certifications options are designed to be completed in a matter of few hours, thus making it a great option for individuals who are new to certification, looking to replace an expired certification, or simply interested in cultivating expertise with selling SAP supply chain solutions. 

Becoming certified in SAP supply chain management solutions will prepare you to gain the confidence and trust in your biggest stakeholder, the Chief Operating Officer (‚ÄúCOO‚Äù). The self-paced learning content will cover these key areas:

  • The end-to-end solution portfolio and how it addresses key priorities for the COO
  • How to position Supply Chain Management solutions in the context of SAP Business Suite
  • How AI is being used today in modern business settings as well as how it fits into the SAP‚Äôs Business AI strategy.
  • Selling SAP Supply Chain Management solutions to the COO through qualification, discovery, and packaging. 

Upon completing the digital learning, your certification attainment is achieved by:

  • Successful completion of a one-hour exam that will include thirty questions derived from the self-paced learning content
  • Submission of one of the following hands-on exercises:
    • Articulating the value of SAP supply chain solutions through an executive pitch
    • Demonstrating the value of SAP supply chain solutions by performing a demo.

Don‚Äôt Delay‚Äîtake advantage of this opportunity to establish your credibility in SAP supply chain management and showcase your accomplishment. With around 5 hours of self-paced learning, this certification option is achievable for any busy professional and will provide tangible value in your field of expertise.

To get started, register for the partner-exclusive session, "Fast Track Your Positioning SAP Business Suite via SAP Supply Chain Management Solutions Certification" to get an overview of everything you need to know to tackle certification with efficiency. You can also visit the SAP Learning Site to review the available certifications and select Positioning SAP Business Suite via SAP Supply Chain Management. With this important investment in certification, you will be on your way to expertly positioning SAP‚Äôs supply chain management solutions in order to solve your customer‚Äôs key challenges and deliver real-world results. 

Lauren Edwards

SAP Industries & Experience, Partner Solution Enablement - Supply Chain Management

entry.title: Error M7053 - Posting period in goods movement
entry.content:
If you find the error M7053 as shown in the image below:

You can try to follow the steps:

First of all, it‚Äôs important to mention that we tried to post goods in 08/2025, but my posting period ended in 06/2025. Therefore, we first need to check and close the period for 07/2025, and only then will we be able to verify the latest period ‚Äî 08/2025.

1. Go to the app "Close Periods":

2. Fill the company code, the period - with the month (e.g. 07/2025) following the last posting period (e.g 06/2025) - and fiscal year boxe. Then select "Check and close periods": 

If you fill the period with the current month, like 08/2025 in this example, you are going to see the log below: 

3. So, after you close the period for 07/2025, you can repeat the same steps for the current month. After that, you should be able to perform postings goods in the current period.

entry.title: Breaking the Silos:Orchestrate end to end Characteristics Based Plans across Planning and Execution
entry.content:
This is a second blog in the series where I explore and update the latest in advanced supply planning in SAP IBP.  Here is a link to the first blog intro blog in this series. If you have not taken a look I highly encourage you to do so.  

https://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-blog-posts-by-sap/unlock-the-potential-of-characteristics-based-planning-cbp-in-sap-ibp/ba-p/13786509 

Blog 2 Intro:

Planners have long dreamed of an uninterrupted flow from proactive attribute-level planning to flawless execution. Now it‚Äôs here. The  latest Characteristics-Based Planning (CBP) in IBP seamlessly orchestrates plans through S/4HANA Segmentation into Manufacturing Planning ePPDS (CDP) ‚Äî all out of the box ‚Äî from strategic / tactical planning to detailed production scheduling and execution. All Natively integrated. No workarounds. No data loss. 

From Plan to Production ‚Äì Attribute-Driven Orchestration Now Out of the Box

Characteristics-Based Planning (CBP) in SAP IBP already empowers planners to manage supply and demand at a granular, attribute level including product and supply chain segments.

We now take this to the next level: CBP plans in IBP can now flow seamlessly through S/4HANA demand supply Segmentation into detailed planning and scheduling in S4HANA Manufacturing planning (ePPDS) running with CDP (characteristics dependent planning) ‚Äî natively, out of the box!

This is not just integration ‚Äî it‚Äôs end-to-end orchestration. Attributes like version, quality grade, or supply chain segment stay intact from tactical planning to shop floor execution, eliminating manual mapping, reducing errors, and ensuring planning intent is preserved in production. The result? Faster responses to demand changes, optimized sequencing, and execution without translation gaps.

here is an overview of the linked process. 

This is CBP without boundaries ‚Äî one seamless flow, one process, one truth, from plan to production. It‚Äôs the kind of end-to-end precision that changes how supply chains run.

additional considerations for set up: please check out the following notes:

SAP Note 3589243 : CBP note for SYPP using Order-Integration 1/2

SAP Note 3589243 : CBP note for SYPP using Order-Integration 2/2

What‚Äôs Next
We‚Äôre exploring how to extend this orchestration to industries with more complex needs ‚Äî Future scenarios could include shelf life‚Äìdriven planning in conjunction with attribute-based component alignment for regulatory-compliant needs, all running seamlessly from IBP to execution. All this also intended on our latest Harmonised planning platform. 

Follow this space for more as we strive to bring the same proactive planning and seamless flows to some of the most regulated and quality-sensitive supply chains in the world. 

SAP Integrated Business Planning SAP Supply Chain Management

entry.title: Cookbook - SAP Query usage statistics
entry.content:
From the context of the migration of ECC to the S4 HANA, the relevance of query reduction may become more of a necessity rather than just a nice-to-have discipline. The reason pertains to the special nature of queries, as they are ‚Äògenerated code‚Äô and not similar to regular custom code. As a whole, making ECC queries compatible with S4 may be a daunting task. Therefore, dedicated efforts will be needed to analyze the usage data of queries so that only the required ones migrate into S4 HANA and not the entire list of queries, as many of them are seldom used or may no longer be needed. The usage will provide quantitative information for IT and business to make an informed decision to determine the queries required for the S4 HANA system.

However, there is no straightforward way to calculate query usage statistics. In this write-up, we will attempt to arrive at a process to calculate the usage statistics of the SAP query.

Step 1: Create a List of Queries

  • Run transaction SQ02: Click on ‚ÄòGo To‚Äô √† Select ‚ÄòQuery Directory‚Äô √† and run wide open

Step 2: Extract raw data for query usage

  • Run transaction SCMON and select ‚ÄòDisplay data.‚Äô

This write-up assumed that there are three ways SAP Query can be called:

  • Direct query call using SQ01
  • Query running in Batch jobs
  • Query called through custom transactions

Usage Data Collection

  • Get usage data for direct call using SQ01 from SCMON using ‚ÄòCalling Request Entry Point‚Äô as Type = ‚ÄòT‚Äô and Name = ‚ÄòSQ01‚Äô (see below)

Next screen

Key steps to be followed:

  • Downloaded the list for ‚ÄòSubmitted Report‚Äô (or DELETE other Request type rows from downloaded report so that we ONLY get ‚ÄòSubmitted Report‚Äô in resultant Excel)
  • Concatenate User Group & Query name in a NEW column before Num of Calls column (for easier VLOOKUP later)
  • Get usage data for batch call using jobs from SCMON using ‚ÄòCalling Request Entry Point‚Äô as Type = ‚ÄòB‚Äô and Name = ‚ÄòAQIC*‚Äô (see below)

In the next screen, filter only Procurement Type as ‚ÄòSSEL‚Äô (as we only want to know the start of selection)

  • Get usage data for custom transaction call from SCMON using ‚ÄòCalling Request Entry Point‚Äô as Type = ‚ÄòT‚Äô and Name = ‚Äòall custom tcode‚Äô that calls a SAP query at execution. (see below)

In the output, filter only records with ‚ÄòProc Type‚Äô as SSEL.

Once we extract raw data, the remaining portion of the work pertains to connecting data from different files and deriving intelligence on collective usage/calls of respective queries (hint: use Mid & VLOOKUP functions in Excel).

Ultimately, sum up all usages to get the final usage (sample output)

Conclusion:

This write has considered one of the possible approaches to simplistically arrive at the usage data for SAP queries, several which tend to grow significantly with the complexity of business processes and user requirements. For system migration, specifically in the context of S4 HANA conversion from ECC, reduction of redundant queries can pay substantial dividend.

entry.title: Driving Resilience Through Intelligent Supply Chain Orchestration
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs global economy, supply chains are under greater pressure than ever before. Shifting trade regulations, evolving geopolitical landscapes, labor shortages, and rising customer expectations are driving unprecedented complexity. Many organizations are realizing that traditional, siloed approaches to supply chain management are no longer enough to remain competitive‚Äîor to simply keep pace with disruption.

The stakes are high: one weak link can set off ripple effects across operations, manufacturing, logistics, and customer delivery. For businesses that rely on complex supplier networks and face unpredictable market dynamics, resilience can‚Äôt be an afterthought, it must be designed into the supply chain itself.

That‚Äôs where supply chain orchestration comes in. Rather than focusing on isolated improvements within functional areas, orchestration integrates processes, data, and decision-making across the entire value chain. With the right strategy, companies can transform supply chains from reactive networks into connected ecosystems that anticipate shifts, adapt rapidly to disruptions, and deliver on customer promises.

To help you explore how orchestration creates more effective and future-ready supply chains, SAP, HP, and Accenture are hosting a  webinar designed for supply chain and operations leaders.

The session will showcase the opportunities orchestration brings to organizations across industries, and offer practical ways to:

  • Improve agility and mitigate disruption with aligned, end-to-end processes
  • Enhance visibility and execution for faster, smarter, AI-supported decisions
  • Strengthen coordination with suppliers and partners while building a foundation for scalable, proactive operations

entry.title: Outbound Transportation from MFG site having EWM,StRM, Lean Warehouse under one Freight Order to DC
entry.content:
Many Industries consider the manufacturing location as a plant in SAP. Under the plant, many storage locations would be available in SAP and some of them would be either IM managed (or Lean Warehouse managed), or Stock Room Managed (StRM) or EWM managed. As a part of the distribution process from the manufacturing site, there would be every chance that the different products from all these types of warehouses need to be shipped to other DC site or to the customer.

This blog covers my personal insights about the outbound process in SAP from MFG (manufacturing) site to other DC (distribution center) or to the customer wherein the different products are picked up from Lean Warehouse, StRM and EWM managed warehouse locations and loaded onto the the same vehicle under the single Freight Order (FO) with the help of SAP EWM and SAP TM ASR integration in basic S/4 HANA licence or in advanced S/4 HANA license using S/4 HANA 2023 FPS02 version. 

Process FLow - 

Process Flow - MFG Site (that has LE, StRM and EWM warehouse) to another DC / Customer in single Freight Order

Master Data -

  1. Maintain Loading Point location for EWM specific warehouse - transaction code # /SCMTMS/LOC3 -

Loading Point - EWM Warehouse

 2. Maintain Loading Point location for StRM specific warehouse - transaction code # /SCMTMS/LOC3 -

Loading Point - StRM Warehouse

3. Maintain Loading Point location for LE specific warehouse - transaction code # /SCMTMS/LOC3 -

Loading Point - LE Warehouse

4. Assign EWM Door in EWM Warehouse to the Loading Point - transaction code # /SCWM/DOOR_SCU -

Assign EWM Door to Loading Point

5. Assign StRM and LE Warehouse specific Door to the Loading Point - transaction code # /SCMTMS/M_ASRDOOR -

Assign StRM and LE Door to Loading Point

Documents in S/4 HANA -

1. Create multiple STO's from MFG plant to another DC.

2. Create multiple OBD's - 

EWM Relevant Delivery

Next -

StRM Relevant Delivery

Next -

Lean WH Relevant Delivery

3. Freight Unit (FU) gets created automatically and is further planned with the help of transportation cockpit automatically / manually and Freight Order (FO) is created and carrier is assigned based on the existing freight agreement arrangements.

Planning of Multiple Freight Units that have warehouse specific Loading Points

4. Perform each warehouse specific steps - picking, packing and staging.

5. Perform Arrival at the Door, Loading, Departure from the Door and PGI at Loading Point of LE Warehouse  - Fiori App - Load/Unload Freight Order.

Update in FO Execution Status after shipping steps in LE Warehouse

6. Perform Arrival at the Door, Loading, Departure from the Door and PGI at Loading Point of StRM Warehouse  - Fiori App - Load/Unload Freight Order.

FO Execution after Shipping steps in StRM Warehouse

7.Perform Arrival at the Door, Loading, Departure from the Door and PGI at Loading Point of EWMM Warehouse - Fiori App - Load/Unload Freight Order.

FO Status Overview at EWM Loading Point

Next -

FO Execution after Shipping steps in EWM Warehouse

Please share your comment and/or feedback in case of any suggestions.
Happy Reading !!!
Thanks
Prashant

entry.title: SAP Field Logistics: Next Generation Kitting & Staging for MRO Industries
entry.content:
For any MRO organization (Maintenance, Repair, and Operations), kitting and staging is a core warehouse activity. On the surface, it seems simple. But in reality, it's a web of complexity, often managed by years of accumulated custom code and custom business process. 

Introducing Standard Kitting & Staging in S/4HANA 2023

With the release of S/4HANA 2023 FPS02, the struggle with custom kitting solutions is over. SAP has delivered a standard, industry-focused solution designed specifically for the intricacies of MRO: End-to-End Kitting & Staging with SAP Field Logistics.

This solution was co-designed with customers to address the real-world challenges you face every day. It‚Äôs built on six core principles to deliver a unified, streamlined process.

1. Centralize Kitting for Remote Operations Efficiently to build, stage, and dispatch kits from a central warehouse directly to remote or field locations, ensuring the right parts are in the right place at the right time.

2. Handle All Types of Goods Seamlessly Support not only inventory managed materials, but also non inventory stock, rental equipment and supplier provided items as part of services, ensuring full visibility and control across all goods movements

3. Empower Your Field Locations Don‚Äôt just ship parts‚Äîship capability. Remote sites can now receive kits, manage kits, add locally held components, and issue the completed kit directly to a maintenance order.

4. Simplify and Standardize Your Processes Whether you operate a single, streamlined plant or manage a complex network of remote locations supported by a supply base, this solution provides a standard, repeatable process to eliminate guesswork and create one version of the truth for your kitting and staging operations.

5. Gain End-to-End Visibility in a Single Place Stop chasing information across different systems. The entire kitting lifecycle‚Äîfrom creation and staging to dispatch and final issuance‚Äîis tracked in a single, accessible repository, giving you unprecedented control and insight. 

6. Scale for Your Environment This isn't a rigid, one-size-fits-all tool. The solution is designed to scale and adapt, supporting various warehouse management setups including Inventory Management (IM), Extended Warehouse Management (EWM), and even hybrid combinations depending on your organisation.

A Future-Proof Foundation for Your MRO Warehouse

By embedding this critical MRO process directly into the S/4HANA core, SAP has delivered a solution that is robust, scalable, and future proof. You can finally retire that aging custom code, move forward with confidence using a standard SAP solution at the base.

This is more than just a new feature; it's a new foundation for operational excellence in your MRO supply chain.

From Order to Staged Kit: A Look at the New Process

So, how does it actually work? The entire process is designed to be intuitive and integrated with maintenance and project business process.  And it all begins exactly where it should: with the demand from the field. 

Step 1: The Kit is Born from the Demand Signal It all starts with a Work Order or Network Order; the kit is automatically created and updated. As the requested materials arrive at the Supply Base, using the Field Logistics Cross-Docking process, the system automatically triggers the tracking milestones and begins the process of bringing everything together.

What truly sets this solution apart is its flexibility in defining the kit. You are no longer locked into a single method like in the past. At the demand plant level, you can define a kit based:

  • The Work Order/Network Order Header: Perfect for bundling all materials where work is planned and scheduled at the header.
  • A Work Order/Network Order Operation: Ideal for creating kits for specific phases or tasks within a more detailed planning and scheduling environment. 
  • A flexible definition via BAdI: For unique business requirements, this allows you to implement custom logic while remaining within the standard framework.

Step 2: Augment the Kit with Local Inventory The process doesn't stop with the initial cross dock. If required, you can easily supplement the base kit by adding stock directly from local base inventory or as more cross docking occurs. This hybrid approach allows you to combine centrally sourced materials with locally available parts for maximum efficiency, speed and tracking.

Step 3: Pack, Stage, and Track with Precision Once complete, the kit can be packed into standard Field Logistics objects like Containers or Packages.

Crucially, every object‚Äîincluding the delivery items ‚Äîcan be assigned to a specific staging location or bin via a dedicated standard field via the Pack Containers (F5786)app. This eliminates guesswork and "lost" kits. The result is pinpoint accuracy on the warehouse floor, where everyone knows exactly what a kit contains, where it is, and which job it‚Äôs for.

Flexibility at the Edge: Managing Kits Upon Arrival

The journey doesn't end when the kit leaves the central warehouse. A core strength of SAP Field Logistics is its ability to track the Supply Chain end to end. The solution is designed to handle several common scenarios:

Scenario 1: The "Base Kit" Handover

In this model, all components have been kitted at the central base. The kit arrives at the remote location fully prepared. The process here is built for speed and simplicity:

  • Receive: The remote site performs a simple goods receipt for the complete kit.
  • Stage: The kit is stored, ready for the job.  The kit can be assigned to a specific staging location or bin via a dedicated standard field.

Scenario 2: The "Remote Kit" Assembly

This scenario is common in industries like Mining or Land-Based Operations where remote sites are highly self-sufficient. Here, no physical goods are shipped from the base. Instead:

  • Demand Signal: The demand is to be supplied fully from the remote site.
  • Local Assembly: The kit is assembled and managed entirely at the remote location using its locally held inventory. This empowers the remote team to take full ownership of the kitting process and support the operations stocking strategy.
  • Stage: The kit is stored, ready for the job.  The kit can be assigned to a specific staging location or bin via a dedicated standard field.

Scenario 3: The "Re-Kit" Hybrid Model

This flexible, hybrid approach offers the best of both worlds. A base kit containing centrally sourced or specialized parts is shipped from the main warehouse. Upon arrival:

  • Receive Base Kit: The initial kit is received at the remote location.
  • Augment Locally: The remote team then adds further components to the kit directly from their local inventory to create the final package.
  • Stage: The kit is stored, ready for the job.  The kit can be assigned to a specific staging location or bin via a dedicated standard field.

This adaptability‚Äîfrom a simple handover to full remote assembly‚Äîensures that no matter your operational model, the system supports your reality on the ground.

Mastering "The Last Mile": Detailed Tracking at the Remote Site

The final journey of a kit‚Äîfrom the remote warehouse shelf to the hands of a technician‚Äîis often a logistical black box. This critical phase, aptly named "The Last Mile," is where parts get misplaced, jobs get delayed, and efficiency breaks down. A common problem is the lack of real-time visibility once a kit is "in the system" but not yet in use.

SAP Field Logistics solves this by introducing key tracking milestones for the entire "Last Mile" lifecycle. Now, users can pinpoint exactly where everything is in real-time.

1. Stage - Once a kit item is received or assembled at the remote location, its status is set to Staged. It is officially logged as staged and ready for the job. The kit can be assigned to a specific staging location or bin using a dedicated standard field. The warehouse knows exactly what is ready and precisely where to find it.

2. Drop - As the job start time approaches, the kit needs to move closer to the point of work. When this happens, its status is updated to Dropped. It can then be assigned to a nominated drop point‚Äîlike a specific laydown yard or workshop area‚Äîagain using a dedicated standard location field.

3. Issue - This is the final, crucial handover. The kits items status is updated to Issued at the moment the technician formally receives the complete kit. This closes the loop on the logistics process, providing a clear and simple audit trail. It confirms that the right parts were delivered to the right person at the right time, minimizing disputes and ensuring the job can begin without delay.

Unlocking Total Visibility: Answering "Where Is My Stuff?"

In any MRO operation, the question "Where is my stuff?" is asked daily. But "stuff" can mean anything‚Äîan individual component, a complex kit for a shutdown, or all the materials for a week's worth of routine maintenance. Answering this question accurately and in real-time has always been a major challenge.

SAP Field Logistics answers this question by tracking every item against extensive, standard milestones, it provides a single source of truth. This critical information is no longer buried in spreadsheets or system tables; it is visualized in intuitive Fiori applications and via exposed API's.

While day-to-day operations are handled in the Manage Kits (F8005) and Manage Logistics (F5082) apps, the consolidated view of this new visibility comes to life in the Logistics Tracking (F7382) app.

First delivered with S/4HANA 2023 FPS00, the Logistics Tracking App has now been specifically enhanced to include the key kitting milestones. This means the "Last Mile" statuses‚ÄîStage, Drop, and Issue‚Äîare now surfaced directly in this central dashboard.

The result is a single view where planners, supervisors, and technicians can see the real-time status of any component or kit, from the central warehouse all the way to the point of use. The question is no longer "Where is my stuff?" but "What do I need to look at next?"

Five Core Capabilities That Transform MRO Logistics

Having walked through the end-to-end process, from the central warehouse to the final handover, we can see how SAP Field Logistics delivers a set of transformative capabilities that directly address the core challenges of MRO supply chains.

1. A Single, Standardized Process from Warehouse to Worksite For the first time, a single, standard process governs the entire kitting lifecycle. From the initial build in a supply base to augmenting a kit at a remote site and issuing it to a technician, the system provides one unified framework. This eliminates process variations, reduces training overhead, and establishes a foundation for operational excellence across the entire organization.

2. Real-Time, End-to-End Visibility The question "Where is my stuff?" is definitively answered. Through the Logistics Tracking App and dedicated Fiori dashboards, you have a single source of truth. By tracking key milestones like Staged, Dropped, and Issued, you gain complete, real-time visibility into the "Last Mile," enabling better decision-making and proactive control.

3. Flexibility for Real-World Operations This is not a rigid, one-size-fits-all solution. It is built to adapt to your reality. Whether you need to define a kit by an entire work order or a specific operation, or whether you manage kits centrally, remotely, or through a hybrid model, the solution provides the flexibility to support your specific business needs.  For example - your operation does not drop but issues directly from staging, this is supported.

4. Integration with Core Maintenance and Warehouse Processes SAP Field Logistics is not a standalone module; it is woven into the digital core. It integrates seamlessly with Maintenance Orders, Network Orders, Logistics Execution (LE), Inventory Management (IM), and Extended Warehouse Management (EWM). This ensures data consistency, prevents information silos, and creates a smooth, automated flow from maintenance planning to field execution.

5. Finally Retire Custom Code and Embrace a Clean Core Perhaps the most strategic benefit is the ability to finally retire your expensive, high-risk custom kitting solutions. By moving this critical functionality into the S/4HANA standard, you can eliminate technical debt, simplify future upgrades, and fully embrace a "clean core" strategy. This reduces your total cost of ownership and positions your organization on a future-proof platform for years to come.

Conclusion: The Future is Standard

For years, managing MRO kitting has meant a compromise. Organizations were forced to choose between a standard SAP process that didn't fully meet their needs or investing heavily in complex, custom-coded solutions that created technical debt and upgrade risk. These "Z-solutions," while functional, were brittle, expensive to maintain, and operated in a silo with each customer to define everything including integration.

With the introduction of SAP Field Logistics in S/4HANA, that era is over.

The journey from a fragmented, high-maintenance custom process to a powerful, flexible, and standard solution is no longer a future ambition‚Äîit is a present reality. We have seen how Field Logistics provides a single, unified framework to:

  • Define and build kits with flexibility.
  • Manage them across diverse remote site scenarios.
  • Track them through "The Last Mile."
  • Visualize their status in real-time for all stakeholders.

This is more than a new module; it is a fundamental shift in strategy. It is the opportunity to finally retire your custom code, shed decades of technical debt, and embrace a "clean core" architecture. It's a chance to align your operations with a future-proof platform that will evolve with your business, not hold it back.

The path forward is no longer about building a better workaround; it's about leveraging a better standard. The future of MRO logistics isn't custom; it's standard and powered by Field Logistics.
